0.46.text:
This board game is at least 4,500 years old
and it was played in the Middle East

6.46.text: by the Sumerians who probably invented it.

9.48.text:
And the thing is, you might think that it
is so old that it is irretrievable to us

14.38.text: that we've got no idea what it was like playing it

20.75.text:
but all sorts of evidence has come to light
so that we know how this game was played

25.76.text: and we can play it now with a great deal of excitement.

32.70.text: I have to say that this does occasionally occur.

35.03.text: So we've decided to bring in a member of the public.

37.40.text: I can't remember the chap's name...

39.44.text:
I'm Tom Scott. I make videos about science,
technology and the world...

44.70.text: I have never played this game before.

46.65.text:
I'm going to give him a very swift overview
of the rules

51.28.text: and then I'm going to play.

52.80.text: Of course I'm going to play very gently at first

54.45.text: because I don't want him to get upset.

56.80.text: But if I have the slightest inclination that he's got the hang of it

59.06.text: I'm going to wipe the floor with him

60.46.text: because it wouldn't do at all for ME who discovered these rules

62.78.text:
and after all it's MY game and I work
in the British Museum SO THERE!

67.74.text: So there's not going to be any FUNNY BUSINESS

70.00.text: with some sort of sleight of hand or any of that kind of stuff

72.34.text: Just follow carefully and you'll see who the superior player is

86.08.text: IRVING: I think we have to start off shaking hands.

89.32.text:
IRVING: That's what one always does under
these circumstances.

91.15.text: I have to tell you a few things about this game before we start.

95.70.text: TOM: I was going to ask.

96.70.text: IRVING: Otherwise we couldn’t even look at it.

98.41.text:
TOM: I was going to say. I was starting to
get a little bit worried about whether I needed

101.99.text:
IRVING: Well you should do, but never mind.
OK that's the first thing

104.66.text: the second thing is is that the original was made in about 2500 BC

113.18.text:
When it was discovered, they found
pieces and dice

117.62.text: and for a long time nobody had any real idea how to play it

120.66.text: but they made things up and made things up...

122.30.text: And then something interesting turned up which is this thing here.

125.84.text: This is a clay tablet written in cuneiform writing as you obviously know.

130.46.text: This was written in the second century BC so miles afterwards

135.42.text: by a Babylonian astronomer who was best friends were Greek astronomers.

138.89.text:
And he wrote this tablet including giving
the rules to how to play it in his day.

148.52.text: So this is the oldest book of rules in the whole world.

152.54.text: Second thing is that we can see that in this very late version it's a very complicated game indeed.

160.58.text: And we're not going to do that now because if I may put it this way

163.03.text: you are relatively speaking a beginner.

164.78.text: We don't want to confuse you on the screen.

167.22.text:
IRVING: So I thought what we would do is start
off with the simple straightforward game

170.92.text: stripped down to the bare minimum.

172.50.text:
TOM: I'm still kind of astonished that there
is something that old just sitting there

177.45.text: IRVING: It is quite remarkable, I agree with you.

179.06.text: This tablet was written to explain a complicated version of the game that everybody already knew.

186.07.text:
IRVING: Right. It's the familiar old game
with new rules.

188.54.text: With betting and things like that in it.

190.74.text: Betting for drink and women and other interesting matters.

193.22.text: So they don't tell you the route, because everybody knows that already.

200.54.text:
IRVING: However, on the basis of this thing
itself, anybody who's played any game like ludo

204.64.text:
or anything like that it's pretty obvious
that it must be like this

207.38.text: that it can't really be anything else.

209.52.text: So if you make that assumption

211.10.text: you can make a really good friendly  normal game like that

215.42.text: but also you can transpose that order under these rules

219.18.text: and also play the more complicated game.

222.88.text: OK so what this is, is the following: it's a race game.

230.02.text: You come in here, you turn the corner

232.34.text:
and go along there. You come out there 
and you come off.

236.44.text: I do obviously the same thing on my side.

239.10.text: And this is the idea. You want to get all your pieces

245.84.text: c) off the end before I do.

249.10.text:
IRVING: What makes it interesting is the following
thing – that here we are at war.

254.86.text: So if you trundle along here calmly and peacefully and put a piece on here

258.17.text: and I get a lucky throw and land on that square

260.84.text: you have to come off again and start again.

264.56.text:
Next thing is that these squares here give
you a second throw

269.50.text: and also and that you are safe on this square here

272.52.text: so if you sit there no one can land on it or knock it off.

274.97.text: TOM: And if you roll and land you just can't move?

278.20.text:
IRVING: You can jump over it but you can't
land on that square whilst someone is there.

282.77.text:
Now the dice are something else. Have
a look.

286.32.text: People always say they are pyramids, but actually they are tetrahedrons

290.00.text: TOM: They are. Triangle based not square based.

291.91.text:
IRVING: Exactly. And they have two of the
four corners marked with a white blob.

297.52.text: IRVING: So when you throw four of them, it's a random number of white blobs

301.94.text: that sticks up and that's how you get your score.

305.23.text:
IRVING: And if you throw four with no white
mark then you lose the turn.

311.13.text: IRVING: So the thing is this, it's quite exciting.

313.50.text: I hope you're braced for this because it's like a window on antiquity.

318.06.text: Because this is a two player race game and before chess

321.92.text: and before backgammon came into the world everybody played this game.

327.73.text: and for that reason one imagines it must have been a good game and it is a good game.

331.40.text: And how do we know? Because you never know who's going to win until the last minute.

337.20.text: So you can come around here think you're going to be off the end and be the winner

339.76.text:
(whooshing sound signalling a death blow)
along I come and you start again.

342.14.text: And that's a really excellent thing.

343.54.text: And all the games are different, they're really exciting.

346.14.text: So someone who has never played it before

348.54.text: against someone who has played it for about 47 years?

IRVING: And of course we have to play speaking

1260.80.text: TOM: A little bit, a little bit...

1270.56.text: If I'm several stones behind then I stand a much better chance of knocking yours off the board.

1277.12.text: TOM: Unless you throw... yes unless you throw zeros.

1287.96.text:
TOM: That one’s safe, that one’s safe,
that one’s safe

1290.40.text: and you have got to move yours ahead.

1294.24.text: IRVING: Statistically then, can you manage a 2?

1299.84.text:
IRVING: See all this statistics stuff is all
very well and good but when it comes to it

1304.23.text: where does it get you? That's my question.

1306.64.text: I never use mathematics or statistics or calculations

1310.09.text: or anything at all like that

1314.64.text: so I just hope for the best...

1316.40.text:
TOM: I'm going to do that because the odds
of you throwing a 1 are slim

1326.56.text: A bit Bond-like, don’t you think, the technique there?

1337.60.text: You've got two chances to kill it now.

1339.58.text: TOM: I have and if I knock it out… 2!

1342.20.text:
IRVING: He’s done it, good! Right, this
is where we have to move hard...

1352.42.text:
TOM: I just have to get these three off
before you knock me off.

1355.91.text:
IRVING: It’s a straight race. This is a
classic kind of conclusion...

1359.72.text: TOM: 2. Ah, that one is safe let's get this one out of the way

1371.48.text: I can't move that one off, that one is blocked by that, and that one is blocked by that.

1389.12.text: IRVING: This is actually what I mean, it is a damn good game.

1391.46.text: TOM: It is, it is... OHHH!

1393.68.text: IRVING: 1, 2, 3, 4. This is not a good position.

1396.14.text: You are going to get one of these 2s and then I'm sunk.

1400.55.text:
IRVING: Oh you have brought out your powerful
reserve throw when you really need it.

1411.74.text:
TOM: Well it’s all down to this isn't it?
1 or a 4.

1414.66.text: IRVING: Well it’s 1/2 and 1/2 isn't it?

1419.68.text: I think that is almost certainly the game but…

1424.18.text: IRVING: I wouldn't say so, if I get 4 it’s a waste.

1430.30.text: IRVING: Any of the others will be helpful.

1433.76.text: IRVING: Oh I say, can I just check that?

1437.42.text:
IRVING: I'll just slide this over to join
the

1440.82.text: I'll just put them in neat row as the winner has to do...

1443.95.text:
IRVING: It’s been a great pleasure and a
great opponent, let me say...

1447.06.text:
TOM: That was really fantastic. I did not
expect a board game from four and a half millennia ago

1455.50.text:
IRVING: Yeah, it is compelling and I will
tell you something amazing

1458.56.text: is that knife edge things are really often the conclusion.

1462.58.text: You can have one there who has to get one

1464.71.text:
and they get 3 and 4 and 3 and 4 and 3 and
4 for ages it works out amazingly.

1469.58.text: TOM: So why don't we play this anymore?

1471.58.text:
IRVING: Well, that's a very good question.
It’s a very good question.

1474.38.text: What we need is a bit of publicity, in some kind of modern electronic form.

1478.09.text: Don't you think that would be a good idea?

1480.64.text: Then people from all over the world will buy one of these boards from the British Museum

1484.18.text: and they will go home and there will be new domestic happiness

1486.68.text: excitement and all that sort of thing.

1488.18.text:
TOM: I am not sure about domestic happiness
if it comes that close all the time.

1490.80.text: IRVING: It always does. It’s rather extraordinary.

1493.64.text: I am really glad we had a game together – Marvellous.

1494.76.text: TOM: Yes. Thank you so much.

1496.19.text:
IRVING: Any time you are passing through of
an evening and you fancy another go.

1498.98.text: TOM: I might take you up on that.

1501.54.text:
You may have noticed that we were talking
about this game using a replica

1505.46.text: which really looks like the original

1507.34.text: with dice which look like the original,

1509.40.text: which is good fun to use and rather exciting.

1512.68.text: Well we used to make that replica but actually at the moment

1515.62.text: we haven't got any more, but we are thinking

1518.76.text: perhaps we should do a new version so that millions of people all around the world

1522.70.text: can enjoy this marvellous game in the correct way and in the correct landscape.

1526.84.text: So just as a matter of interest if you thought that was a good idea, tell us in the comment section.
